title_narrative: The Netherlands Mine Action and Cluster Munitions Programme 2020-2024 - Yemen
description_narrative: Under the Mine Action and Cluster Munitions Program, HI will reduce impacts of explosive ordnance and armed conflicts on the crisis-affected population of Yemen through comprehensive armed violence reduction activities including Explosive Ordnance and armed conflict prevention awareness, conduct non-technical survey as part of land release process, and integrated support to victims of explosive ordnance.
result_title_narrative: Output 1.1 - Risk of Explosive Ordnance related deaths and injuries are reduced
Output 1.3 - HI MA processes are conflict sensitive
Output 2.1: National Mine Action Standard (NMAS) on Victim Assistance (VA) is initiated based on IMAS on VA 13.10 in collaboration with the NMAA and HMA sectors
Output 2.2: Enhanced capacities to plan and contribute to better respond to EO victims and to strengthen VA specific efforts of NMAA, HMA actors, VA organizations
Output 2.3: Access to services and victims referral systems are strengthened for EO victims and survivors
Output 1.1 - Risk of Explosive Ordnance related deaths and injuries are reduced
Output 1.2 : Prioritization to support NMAA to clear, reduce and cancel EO contaminated lands are improved
Output 1.3 - HI MA processes are conflict sensitive
Output 2.1: National Mine Action Standard (NMAS) on Victim Assistance (VA) is initiated based on IMAS on VA 13.10 in collaboration with the NMAA and HMA sectors
Output 2.2: Enhanced capacities to plan and contribute to better respond to EO victims and to strengthen VA specific efforts of NMAA, HMA actors, VA organizations
Output 2.3: Access to services and victims referral systems are strengthened for EO victims and survivors

result_indicator_period_actual_comment_n: Lahj: 21 beneficiaries (6 women, 15 men)Aden: 35 beneficiaries (5 girls, 18 boys, 7 women, 5 men). Activities commence in earnest during Qr 14 after Eid.In the north of Yemen, HI is facing challenges in securing a sub-agreement with the authorities, and continuous efforts are being made to hold several meetings to follow up and facilitating getting the approval.

Lahj: 2412 beneficiaries (938 girls, 701 boys, 487 women, 286 men) Aden: 241 beneficiaries (67 girls, 66 boys, 53 women, 55 men). In the north of Yemen, HI is still facing challanges and making significant efforts to finalize the approval process and provide all the clarifications requested by the authorities to facilitate the process

8569 BNFs (2835 men, 1143  women, 2801 boys and 1790 girls)Lahj: 2759 BNFs (435 men, 597  women, 764 boys and 963 girls)Aden: 276 BNFs (60 men, 60  women, 84 boys and 72 girls)Hodaidah: 5534 BNFs( 1953 boys, 755 girls, 2340 men, 486 women).In the south of Yemen, HI worked in both Aden and lahj with small capacities, meanwhile meeting and discussions took place with YEMAC and YMACC to get the Cooperating prtner agreement to second staff from YEMAC to strengthen the EORE implementation, and final reply from the authorities is to be given by October.In the north of Yemen, there were restructuring efforts within the government, including changes in employees, roles and responsibilities, which created additional challenges in securing approvals. As a result, more coordination meetings and follow-ups were required. In response to the floods that displaced many mines and explosive ordnance (EO) in Hodeidah, the initial approval was issued for only EORE sessions, along with NTS and EOD. The final approval was planned to be issued in October.HI in north with the collaboration with YEMAC conducted EORE sessions for 5534 BNFs (2340 men, 486 women, 1679 boys, 755 girls) , and it is planned to conduct similar sessions in Hajjah and Sana'a in October as per the need.

Lahj: 2 out of 2 beneficiaries improved in knowledge (100%).Aden: 1 out of 1 beneficiaries improved in Knowledge (100%) Target of 70% across the board will be achieved.In the north of Yemen, no progress has been made as HI has not yet received the approval.

"Lahj: 125 BNFs ( 32 men, 39  women, 20 boys and 34 girls) out of  125 BNFs ( 32 men, 39  women, 20 boys and 34 girls)  improved 100% in knowledge after the sessions.Aden: 17 BNFs ( 8 men, 5  women, 2 boys and 2 girls) out of 17 BNFs ( 8 men, 5  women, 2 boys and 2 girls)  improved 100% in knowledge after the sessions."HI in the north of Yemen was unable to achieve as the final approval has not been received yet. However, HI is continuing its efforts through several meetings, clarifications, and follow-ups to finalize the approval and begin implementation.

Total: 159 BNFs ( 49 men, 51  women, 23 boys and 36 girls) out of  159 BNFs ( 49 men, 51  women, 23 boys and 36 girls)  improved 100% in knowledge after the sessions.Lahj: 142 BNFs ( 41 men, 46  women, 21 boys and 34 girls) out of  142 BNFs ( 41 men, 46  women, 21 boys and 34 girls)  improved 100% in knowledge after the sessions.Aden: 17 BNFs ( 8 men, 5  women, 2 boys and 2 girls) out of 17 BNFs ( 8 men, 5  women, 2 boys and 2 girls)  improved 100% in knowledge after the sessions.In th South of Yemen, HI is working on a proper timing of reaching the targets and with using adequate IEC materials and pre and post tests, also distributing refreshment in schools and IDPs' camps. In addition to that, staff are from the same areas of work to facilitate more access and accepetance from the communities.Due to delays in securing approvals in the north, HI conducted pre-tests to measure awareness before the EORE sessions. A post-test will be conducted at the end of the sessions to assess improvements, and this indicator will be updated at the conclusion of the intervention.
Training to be conducted in Q2 of 2024

No approvals were given to conduct this activity due to the lack of fund for YMACC/YEMAC as the national mine action authority as they were not fully operational attending their offices, however plans were made after discussing with them to take place on December.

No approvals were given to conduct this activity due to the lack of fund for YMACC/YEMAC as the national mine action authority as they were not fully operational attending their offices, however plans were made after discussing with them to take place on December.

12 NTS were achieved in Hodaidah In northern Yemen, following initial approval for Explosive Ordnance Risk Education (EORE) sessions and Non-Technical Survey (NTS) operations as part of the response to the flooding in the Hodidah region, efforts were focused on addressing the displacement caused by the floods and the resulting risks from landmines and explosive ordnance. In collaboration with the Yemen Executive Mine Action Center (YEMAC), a total of 12 NTS surveys were conducted to assess and mitigate the threats posed by mines and explosive remnants of war (ERW).In south,No NTS task orders were given to conduct this activity due to the lack of fund for YMACC/YEMAC as the national mine action authority as they were not fully operational attending their offices, however , with the discussions of the cooperating partner agreement, also task orders have been requested and to be given by October.

No NTS task orders were given to conduct this activity due to the lack of fund for YMACC/YEMAC as the national mine action authority, as they were not fully operational, however , with the discussions of the cooperating partner agreement, also task orders have been requested and to be given by October.

In the South, one online conflict transformation/sensitivity  training took place for 8 HI staff (5 females, 3 males) for Aden and Mokha , and remaining 1 activity is shifted to be conducted in early December.
In the South of Yemen, this is planned in December.

Lahj: 13119 Beneficiaries (1116 men, 1685 women, 5815 boys and 4503 girls).Aden: 276 Beneficiaries (60 men, 60  women, 84 boys and 72 girls).Hodeidah: 5534 Beneficiaries (2340 men, 486  women, 1953 boys and 755 girls).Sanaa: 3000 Beneficiaries (587 men, 319 women, 1206 boys and 888 girls).Hajjah: 2824 Beneficiaries (1537 men, 53 women, 1183 boys and 51 girls).Total : 24753 Beneficiaries (5640 men, 2603 women, 10241 boys, 6269 girls).HI in Yemen conducted EORE sessions for a total of 24,753 beneficiaries (5,640 men, 2,603 women, 10,241 boys, and 6,269 girls). In the North, in addition to what was achieved before October in Hodaidah (5,534 Beneficiaries: 2,340 men, 486 women, 1,953 boys, and 755 girls). After October 24, HI had several discussions and coordinated with YEMAC. As a result, HI conducted EORE sessions in Sana�a for 3,000 beneficiaries (587 men, 319 women, 1,206 boys, and 888 girls) and in Hajjah for 2,824 beneficiaries (1,537 men, 53 women, 1,183 boys, and 51 girls), based on the needs and recommendations from YEMAC. In the South, all necessary coordination was conducted, and HI conducted sessions in Lahj for 13,119 beneficiaries (1,116 men, 1,685 women, 5,815 boys, and 4,503 girls), and in Aden for 276 beneficiaries (60 men, 60 women, 84 boys, and 72 girls).

Lahj: 408 Beneficiaries ( 68 men, 88  women, 131 boys and 121 girls) out of  512 beneficiaries ( 73 men, 97  women, 190 boys and 152 girls)  representing 80% of beneficiaries having improved knowledge about the EO after the sessions.Aden: 17 Beneficiaries ( 8 men, 5  women, 2 boys and 2 girls) out of 17 beneficiaries ( 8 men, 5  women, 2 boys and 2 girls)  representing 100%  of beneficiaries having improved knowledge about EO after the sessions.Hodeidah: 112 Beneficiaries ( 45 men, 10  women, 51 boys and 6 girls) out of 131 beneficiaries ( 62 men, 10  women,52 boys and 7 girls)  representing 85% of beneficiaries having improved knowledge about EO after the sessions.Total: 537 Beneficiaries ( 121 men, 103  women, 184 boys and 129 girls) out of  660 beneficiaries ( 143 men, 112  women, 244 boys and 161 girls) representing 81% of beneficiaries having improved knowledge about EO  after the sessions.HI conducted pre- and post-tests for a total of 660 beneficiaries (143 men, 112 women, 244 boys, and 161 girls). Out of these, 537 beneficiaries (121 men, 103 women, 184 boys, and 129 girls) showed an improvement of 81%. o408 Beneficiaries ( 68 men, 88  women, 131 boys and 121 girls) out of 512 beneficiaries ( 73 men, 97  women, 190 boys and 152 girls), representing 80% of Lahj EORE beneficiaries, improved their knowledge of EO risks after the sessions.In Aden 17 Beneficiaries (8 men, 5 women, 2 boys, and 2 girls) out of 17 beneficiaries (8 men, 5 women, 2 boys, and 2 girls) representing 100 % of Aden EORE beneficiaries, improved their knowledge of EO risks after the sessions.In Hodeidah: 112 Beneficiaries (45 men, 10 women, 51 boys, and 6 girls) out of 131 beneficiaries (62 men, 10 women, 52 boys, and 7 girls)representing 85% of Hodeidah EORE beneficiaries, improved their knowledge of EO risks after the sessions..

Aden: 30 Focal Points (16 Men, 14 Women), Dec 2024.During the reporting period, HI conducted community focal point training in Aden for 30 focal points (16 Men, 14 Women).In the South, this was conducted through coordination with YMACC/YEMAC to obtain the approvals needed as well as the nomination list for the participants with criteria set in advanced followed by providing the training management plan (TMP) and training request.

No approvals were given to conduct this activity due to the lack of fund for YMACC/YEMAC as the national mine action authority as they were not fully operational attending their offices, however plans were made after discussing with them to take place on December.
HI coordinated with YMACC to get approval for mass media  in Aden and Lahj: 3 of Inclusive and gender sensitive mass media campaigns delivered billboards, radio and signboards.

12 NTS were achieved in Hodaidah In northern Yemen, following initial approval for Explosive Ordnance Risk Education (EORE) sessions and Non-Technical Survey (NTS) operations as part of the response to the flooding in the Hodidah region, efforts were focused on addressing the displacement caused by the floods and the resulting risks from landmines and explosive ordnance. In collaboration with the Yemen Executive Mine Action Center (YEMAC), a total of 12 NTS surveys were conducted to assess and mitigate the threats posed by mines and explosive remnants of war (ERW).In south,No NTS task orders were given to conduct this activity due to the lack of fund for YMACC/YEMAC as the national mine action authority as they were not fully operational attending their offices, however , with the discussions of the cooperating partner agreement, also task orders have been requested and to be given by October.

Hodaidah: 12 NTSLahj: 62 NTSSanaa: 20 NTSTotal: 94 NTSIn collaboration with YEMAC, HI in Yemen conducted a total of 94 NTS surveys to assess and mitigate the threats posed by mines and explosive remnants of war (ERW). In the North, HI conducted 32 NTS surveys in Hodidah and Sana�a, while 62 NTS surveys were carried out in the South. HI provided the necessary materials, equipment, and risk assessments prior to fieldwork. Coordination efforts were made with local authorities and stakeholders to facilitate team movement, equipment usage, and access to designated work areas. The surveys were conducted by a trained and qualified team, working in close coordination with other field teams (EORE, EOD). The NTS identified safe areas, suspected Hazard Areas (SHA), and Confirmed Hazard Areas (CHA). These areas were clearly marked to warn the community and help identify potential hazards.

No NTS task orders were given to conduct this activity due to the lack of fund for YMACC/YEMAC as the national mine action authority, as they were not fully operational, however , with the discussions of the cooperating partner agreement, also task orders have been requested and to be given by October.

Lahj: 2 Hazard areasSanaa: 32 Hazard areasHI identified and reported 34 hazared areas 2 of them in lahj and 32 were in Sana'a These areas were clearly marked to warn the community and help identify potential hazards..identified and reported 34 hazardous areas, 2 of which were in Lahj and 32 in Sana'a. These areas were clearly marked to warn the community and help identify potential hazards.

No NTS task orders were given to conduct this activity due to the lack of fund for YMACC/YEMAC as the national mine action authority, as they were not fully operational, however , with the discussions of the cooperating partner agreement, also task orders have been requested and to be given by October.

Lahj: 1 EOD spot task reported by the EORE team and reported to NMAA to refer to another IP with EO capacity in that area to take an action and this was also submitted into IMSMA as a (marked) EOD report.

In the South, one online conflict transformation/sensitivity  training took place for 8 HI staff (5 females, 3 males) for Aden and Mokha , and remaining 1 activity is shifted to be conducted in early December.

Aden: 1st training = 8 Participants (3 Men, 5 Women), Dec. 2024.Aden: 2nd  training = 29 Participants (24 Men, 5 Women), Dec 2024.Aden: 3rd Refresher training = 46 Participants (36 Men, 10 Women), Dec 2024.Total : Aden 83 participants (63 Men, 20 women).HI implemented two conflict sensitivity trainings and one refresher training to increase the awareness about the type of conflict and the training focused on the conflict related the MA projects and related cross projects to understand the context by analysing the conflict and apply the conflict transformation methods and work with best techniques to assure implementing the activities with positive impact on the organization and communities.
In the South of Yemen, this is planned in December.

Aden: 1st workshop = 34 Participants (29 Men, 5 Women), Dec 2024.Aden: 2nd workshop = 40 Participants (36 Men, 4 Women), Dec 2024.Total: 74 participants (65 Men, 9 women).In south, HI conducted two workshops about conflict sensitivity for EORE and land release areas and a good analysis for hazard areas to ensure safe access to hazardous areas that were targeted through the project.
In the South of Yemen, this is planned in December.

Aden: 1st workshop = 49 Participants (34 Men, 15 Women), Dec 2024.Aden: 2nd workshop = 42 Participants (28 Men, 14 Women), Dec 2024.Aden: 3rd workshop = 41 Participants (28 Men, 13 Women), Dec 2024.Sanaa:  1st workshop   = 39 persons (26 Men and 13 Women).2nd workshop  = 51 person (36 Men and 15 women).3rd workshop  = 56 person (40 Men and 16 women).Total: 6 workshops (278 Participants).HI facilitated 6 workshops in Yemen for 278 participants to develop an action plan and create NMAS on VA, in partnership and coordination with HMA partners, as well as YEMACC and YEMAC. In the North, 3 workshops were conducted for 147 participants in Sana�a, while in the South, 3 workshops were held for 132 participants in Aden.
In the South of Yemen, this is planned in December.In nNorth of Yemen, this indicator will be updated in November, as the activity was rescheduled to take place following final approval

Aden: 9 Key Humanitarian Mine Action (HMA) operators/organizations are trained,  with 40 participants (13 Men and 7 Women participants), Dec 2024.Sanaa: 6 Key HMA operators/organizations are trained with 23 participants (18 Men, 5 Women), 12 Dec.24.Total : 43 participants (31 Men, 12 Women) from 15 Key HMA operators/organisation were trained, Dec 2024.HI conducted two trainings in December 2024: One in the North for 6 key HMA operators (including 18 men, 5 women) and one in the South for 9 key HMA operators (including 13 men, & 7 women). The trainings focused on VA-specific efforts, including victim data collection and analysis, NMAS on VA, best responses to VA, and referral mechanisms.

In the South of Yemen, this is planned in December.As the final approval has not yet been issued and is expected to be finalized in October, the activity for this indicator has been rescheduled to November in North of Yemen

Aden: 16  OPDs are trained (18 Men, 15 Women) making it a total of 33 participant, Dec 2024.Sanaa: 15 OPDs are trained (30 Men, 18 Women ) making it a total of 48 participants, 3rd and 4th Dec 24.Total: 31 OPDs are trained (48 Men, 33 Women), Dec 2024.HI conducted two training sessions for 81 participants (48 men, 33 women) from 31 OPDs in the South and North. The training focused on NMA for VA, the referral system, and emergency response. The aim was to strengthen the referral system for victims to ensure a rapid response and streamlined data collection through a unified channel between all HMAA and NGOs.

Lahj: 11 Victims  (11 men, 0  women, 0 boys and 0 girls)In the South, all VA and accidents data are registered into IMSMA on time. In addition to refer them as well.In northern Yemen, the activity for this indicator will be implemented immediately after final approval, which is expected to be completed in October.

Lahj: 92 Victims  (76 men, 11  women, 2 boys and 3 girls).Sanaa: 46 Victims (33 men, 7 women, 6 boys and 0 girls).Hajjah: 5 Victims (5 men).Hodeidah:  20 Victims (18 men, 2 women, 0 boys and 0 girls).Total 163 victims (132men, 20 women , 8 boys, 3 girls).HI provided services to 163 victims in the South and North, including rehabilitation services, MHPSS, assistive devices, and transportation fees to facilitate their accessibility to services. Additionally, all VA data was entered into the IMSMA system. Some victims were also referred to other NGOs and the AVR team for further support.

In the South, all VA and accidents data are registered into IMSMA on time. In addition to refer them as well.In the North, as mentioned in the previous indicator, the activity will be implemented immediately after final approval, which is expected to be granted in October.

Lahj: 52 Victims  (34 men, 9 women, 5 boys and 4 girls).Hodiedah : 24 victims (17 men, 2 women, 4 boys, 1 girls).Total: 76 Victims  (51 men, 11 women, 9 boys and 5 girls).HI identified 76 victims in the South and North in need of external services. These victims were referred to other service providers and provided with transportation costs from HI to access the services. HI CMO followed up to ensure their needs were addressed.

In the South of Yemen, this activity will be updated in November by all HI field staff, EORE, NTS, PTs, and inclusion field staff.In northern Yemen, the activity is going to be conducted during the EORE sessions and NTS and will be updated in November.

Lahj: 2500 Beneficiaries  (159 men, 436  women, 946 boys and 959 girls).Sanaa: 3000 Beneficiaries (587 men, 319 women, 1206 boys and 888 girls).Total 5500 Beneficiaries (746 men, 755 women, 2152 boys, 1847 girls).HI provided IEC materials including information on access to service provisions through EORE, NTS, comprehensive health and inclusion activities to 5500 beneficiaries in north and south.
